data.title: Great K a Train Robbery, First Edition
data.meta_description: The Great K. and A. Train Robbery by Paul L. ford and a great selection of related books, art and collectibles available now at AbeBooks.com.
data.text:
A nice copy of the attractive First English edition very different to the American, issued in the same year. The story was first serialised in Lippincott's Monthly Magazine in 1896 and in 1926 made into an American western film directed by Lewis Seiler. Starring Tom Mix and Dorothy Dwan (and an annonymous John Wain). The author was murdered in his Manhattan home by his brother, Malcolm Webster Ford, at one time the most famous amateur athlete in the US, who then committed suicide. 8vo.viii 200pps tissue guarded frontispiece and two colour title page. From the library of Stewart Dewsbery with his attractive C Hamilton Ellis Bookplate to the pastedown.

Hardcover. Condition: Very Good. No Jacket. First American Edition. Book in VG condition with faded white splotches on cover. Pages are untrimmed as issued on bottom and fore edge, top is gilded. There is a tissue guard on the frontis-piece This is a great little folksy story, from the late 19th century, that gives the reader a tongue and cheek taste of the times Mylar protected. First Edition, first issue with "train" missing from title page. A great and rare collectible for Western era enthusiasts. Size: 7.25x5".

Hardcover. Condition: Good. First edition. 12mo, contemporary blue cloth; gilt titles stamped on top cover The unusual first with the idea of 'train' on the title-page expressed with sketches of a locomotive engine [BAL 6213]. In the second printing the word 'train' was added. Ford's only mystery. [Victorian Detective Fiction #151].

Condition: Good. NY: Dodd Mead and Company, 1897. 1897. Good. - Octavo, 6-1/2 inches high by 4-1/4 inches wide. Hardcover, bound in pictorial tan cloth titled in black with multiple vignettes of train engines stamped in red & black on spine & front cover. The covers are cocked, bumped, soiled & darkened. viii & 200 pages illustrated with a black & white frontispiece & color title vignettes. There is some light foxing & soiling to the endpapers with an early owner's name and the date penned on the front endpaper. The title page is soiled with scattered minor light staining to throughout. Good. First edition in book form [after a special magazine edition].

Decorative Cloth. Condition: Very Good. First Edition. First Edition , Second State , Word "Train" in title on title page. Name of previous owner on front endpaper. Light wear to cloth. Some insect marks. Graphics on front board are very bright. Interior is clean , no marks. Overall , a very good copy.

Hardcover. Condition: Very Good. First Edition. 8vo. Publisher's blue pictorial cloth with gilt lettering to the front board and spine. Very light wear to the cloth at the corners and to the head and foot of the spine, with a spine fade and a lightly soiled rear board. Bookplate of Felix Trautmann.

Hardcover. Condition: Very Good. No Jacket. 1st Edition. First Edition thus. Decorated binding; design not attributed. No DJ or initial sales price data. Wear and soiling of the covers and spine; spine darkened. Rear hinge weakened but holding. Age-commensurate tanning of the pages. Childish drawing on the RFEP; otherwise, unmarked pages. This work has been reissued many times in many formats, but nothing compares with owning a copy in an early original state. More images and/or description can be sent on request. Condition: Good+.

1st Edition. 1st Edition. First Edition, first issue lacking 'train' on the title-page. A near fine copy in decorated blue cloth, (previous collector's discreet name to the front pastedown, hinges strengthened), gilt titles to the spine and front board with black and red locomotive design, t.e.g. Housed in a black cloth slipcase with chemise, red leather labels, gilt titles. A bright, fresh copy of this western novel based on the actual foiling of a train robbery and originally published as a serial in the 1896 Lippincott Monthly Magazine. Adapted into the 1926 film with Tom Mix and John Wayne as an uncredited extra.
